Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded school hallway, watching my stepbrother trudge toward me, his shoulders slumped. He barely looked up, but I could see the redness in his eyes. I knew I was supposed to be there for him, to listen and offer comfort, especially after the way things had been at home lately. But I glanced at my phone—today was voting day, and I had promised myself I’d do my civic duty. At the polling station, the official’s voice rang out: “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name fit, but the new line was longer and slower. I hesitated, torn between following the rules and wanting to get home quickly to check on my stepbrother. The expectation to support him weighed on me, but so did the pressure to be a responsible voter and follow instructions. My heart pounded as I stood in the middle of the polling place, wrestling with the demands of both roles, feeling like I was letting someone down no matter what I chose.
